natural problem: Tara rolls three standard dice once.  What is the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled will be three or more?  Express your answer as a percent.
natural solution: The smallest possible number that Tara can roll is a 3, by getting a 1 on each die.
Thus, she will always get a sum of three or more. Our answer is $\boxed{100\%}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability"
and h1 : "probability \<le> 1"
and h2 : "probability = (\<Sum> (x, y, z) \<in> {(x, y, z). x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> z \<in> {1..6} \<and> x + y + z \<ge> 3}. 1) / (6 * 6 * 6)"
shows  "probability = 1"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Tara rolls three standard dice once.  What is the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled will be three or more?  Express your answer as a percent. The final Answer is 100\%
 ### Proof
 The smallest possible number that Tara can roll is a 3, by getting a 1 on each die.
 Thus, she will always get a sum of three or more. Our answer is $\boxed{100\%}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability"
and h1 : "probability \<le> 1"
and h2 : "probability = (\<Sum> (x, y, z) \<in> {(x, y, z). x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> z \<in> {1..6} \<and> x + y + z \<ge> 3}. 1) / (6 * 6 * 6)"
shows  "probability = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider an experiment where three fair six-sided dice are rolled. Calculate the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled on the three dice is greater than or equal to 3. The final answer is 1.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability \<and> probability \<le> 1"
and h1 : "probability = (\<Sum>(a::nat, b::nat, c::nat) \<in> {1..6} \<times> {1..6} \<times> {1..6}. if a + b + c \<ge> 3 then 1 else 0) / (6 * 6 * 6)"
shows  "probability * 100 = 100"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Tara rolls three standard dice once.  What is the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled will be three or more?  Express your answer as a percent. The final Answer is 100\%
 ### Proof
 The smallest possible number that Tara can roll is a 3, by getting a 1 on each die.
 Thus, she will always get a sum of three or more. Our answer is $\boxed{100\%}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability \<and> probability \<le> 1"
and h1 : "probability = (\<Sum>(a::nat, b::nat, c::nat) \<in> {1..6} \<times> {1..6} \<times> {1..6}. if a + b + c \<ge> 3 then 1 else 0) / (6 * 6 * 6)"
shows  "probability * 100 = 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: What is the probability, expressed as a percentage, that the sum of the numbers rolled on three fair 6-sided dice is greater than or equal to 3? The final answer is 100%.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "card (UNIV :: real set) = 6"
and h1 : "finite (UNIV :: real set)"
and h2 : "P = {x + y + z | x y z. x \<in> (UNIV :: real set) \<and> y \<in> (UNIV :: real set) \<and> z \<in> (UNIV :: real set) \<and> x + y + z \<ge> 3}"
shows  "card P / card (UNIV :: real set) ^ 3 = 1"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Tara rolls three standard dice once.  What is the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled will be three or more?  Express your answer as a percent. The final Answer is 100\%
 ### Proof
 The smallest possible number that Tara can roll is a 3, by getting a 1 on each die.
 Thus, she will always get a sum of three or more. Our answer is $\boxed{100\%}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "card (UNIV :: real set) = 6"
and h1 : "finite (UNIV :: real set)"
and h2 : "P = {x + y + z | x y z. x \<in> (UNIV :: real set) \<and> y \<in> (UNIV :: real set) \<and> z \<in> (UNIV :: real set) \<and> x + y + z \<ge> 3}"
shows  "card P / card (UNIV :: real set) ^ 3 = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: There is a finite set of real numbers with exactly 6 elements. Find the probability that the sum of any three elements from this set is greater than or equal to 3. The final answer is 1.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..6}"
and h1 : "B = {1..6}"
and h2 : "C = {1..6}"
and h3 : "finite A \<and> finite B \<and> finite C"
and h4 : "\<forall>x y z. x \<in> A \<and> y \<in> B \<and> z \<in> C \<longrightarrow> x + y + z \<ge> 3"
shows  "100 = (card (A \<times> B \<times> C) / real (card (A \<times> B \<times> C))) * 100"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Tara rolls three standard dice once.  What is the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled will be three or more?  Express your answer as a percent. The final Answer is 100\%
 ### Proof
 The smallest possible number that Tara can roll is a 3, by getting a 1 on each die.
 Thus, she will always get a sum of three or more. Our answer is $\boxed{100\%}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1..6}"
and h1 : "B = {1..6}"
and h2 : "C = {1..6}"
and h3 : "finite A \<and> finite B \<and> finite C"
and h4 : "\<forall>x y z. x \<in> A \<and> y \<in> B \<and> z \<in> C \<longrightarrow> x + y + z \<ge> 3"
shows  "100 = (card (A \<times> B \<times> C) / real (card (A \<times> B \<times> C))) * 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Consider three sets A, B, and C, each containing the numbers from 1 to 6. Determine the percentage of possible triples $(x, y, z)$, with $x \in A$, $y \in B$, and $z \in C$, such that the sum $x + y + z \geq 3$. The final answer is 100%.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 0 \<le> P x \<and> P x \<le> 1"
and h1 : "P (\<lambda> x. \<exists> a b c. a + b + c = x \<and> 1 \<le> a \<and> a \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> b \<and> b \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> c \<and> c \<le> 6) = 1"
shows  "P (\<lambda> x. x \<ge> 3) = 100"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Tara rolls three standard dice once.  What is the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled will be three or more?  Express your answer as a percent. The final Answer is 100\%
 ### Proof
 The smallest possible number that Tara can roll is a 3, by getting a 1 on each die.
 Thus, she will always get a sum of three or more. Our answer is $\boxed{100\%}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 0 \<le> P x \<and> P x \<le> 1"
and h1 : "P (\<lambda> x. \<exists> a b c. a + b + c = x \<and> 1 \<le> a \<and> a \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> b \<and> b \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> c \<and> c \<le> 6) = 1"
shows  "P (\<lambda> x. x \<ge> 3) = 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Determine the probability of obtaining a sum of at least 3 when rolling three standard six-sided dice. Express your answer as a percentage. The final answer is 100%.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 0 \<le> P x \<and> P x \<le> 1"
and h1 : "P (\<lambda> x y z. x + y + z \<ge> 3) = 1"
and h2 : "P (\<lambda> x y z. x + y + z \<le> 18) = 1"
shows  "P (\<lambda> x y z. x + y + z \<ge> 3 \<and> x + y + z \<le> 18) = 100 / 100"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Tara rolls three standard dice once.  What is the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled will be three or more?  Express your answer as a percent. The final Answer is 100\%
 ### Proof
 The smallest possible number that Tara can roll is a 3, by getting a 1 on each die.
 Thus, she will always get a sum of three or more. Our answer is $\boxed{100\%}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 0 \<le> P x \<and> P x \<le> 1"
and h1 : "P (\<lambda> x y z. x + y + z \<ge> 3) = 1"
and h2 : "P (\<lambda> x y z. x + y + z \<le> 18) = 1"
shows  "P (\<lambda> x y z. x + y + z \<ge> 3 \<and> x + y + z \<le> 18) = 100 / 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the probability $P$ of an event where $x + y + z \geq 3$ and $x + y + z \leq 18$, given that the probability of $x + y + z \geq 3$ is 1 and the probability of $x + y + z \leq 18$ is 1. The final answer is 1.

fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>(i, j, k)\<in>{(i, j, k). i \<in> {1..6} \<and> j \<in> {1..6} \<and> k \<in> {1..6} \<and> i + j + k \<ge> 3}. 1) / 216"
shows  "P = 100 / 100"

shows  "P = 100 / 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: What is the probability of the sum of three dice being greater than or equal to 3, given that each die has 6 faces with numbers from 1 to 6? Express your answer as a fraction. The final answer is $\frac{100}{100}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum> (a, b, c) \<in> {1..6} \<times> {1..6} \<times> {1..6}. (if a + b + c \<ge> 3 then 1 else 0)) / (6 * 6 * 6)"
shows  "p = 1"

fixes p :: real

shows  "p = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A six-sided die is rolled three times. What is the probability that the sum of the three rolls is greater than or equal to 3? The final answer is 1.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "finite { (a,b,c) | a b c. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} }"
and h1 : "P { (a,b,c) | a b c. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a + b + c \<ge> 3 } = x"
shows  "x = 100"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Tara rolls three standard dice once.  What is the probability that the sum of the numbers rolled will be three or more?  Express your answer as a percent. The final Answer is 100\%

 Thus, she will always get a sum of three or more. Our answer is $\boxed{100\%}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "finite { (a,b,c) | a b c. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} }"
and h1 : "P { (a,b,c) | a b c. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6} \<and> a + b + c \<ge> 3 } = x"
shows  "x = 100"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the number of ways to choose three integers $a, b, c$ from the set $\{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$ such that $a + b + c \geq 3$. The final answer is $100$.
